Text: God is renowned in Judah; in Israel His name is great.
Context: This introduces the theme of God’s greatness and fame, especially among His chosen people.

Text: His tent is in Salem, His dwelling place in Zion.
Context: Salem (ancient Jerusalem) and Zion are depicted as the dwelling of God, signifying His closeness and protection.

Text: There He shattered the flaming arrows, the shield, the sword, and the weapons of war. Selah
Context: God is depicted as a divine warrior who brings an end to conflict, emphasizing His power over warfare.

Text: You are resplendent with light, more majestic than the mountains of prey.
Context: The verse uses metaphorical language to compare God‘s glory and majesty to great mountains, symbolizing strength.

Text: The valiant lie plundered; they sleep their last sleep. Not one of the warriors can lift his hands.
Context: This verse describes the powerlessness of even the bravest warriors in the face of God’s might—they cannot even move.

Text: At Your rebuke, O God of Jacob, both chariot and horse lie still.
Context: The emphasis here is on God‘s ability to halt the mechanisms of war (chariots and horses) with just a rebuke, stressing His authority.

Text: You alone are to be feared. When You are angry, who can stand before You?
Context: The verse speaks to the fear of the Lord, which is a form of respect and recognition of His power, especially in His anger.

Text: From heaven You pronounced judgment, and the land feared and was quiet—
Context: The imagery of God’s judgment coming from heaven implies a divine perspective that is beyond human challenge.

Text: when You, O God, rose up to judge, to save all the afflicted of the land. Selah
Context: God‘s judgment is also seen as a means of deliverance for the oppressed, showing His concern for justice.

Text: Surely Your wrath against men brings You praise, and the survivors of Your wrath are restrained.
Context: This reflects on how even God’s wrath ultimately leads to His glorification and has a restraining effect on those who witness it.

Text: Make vows to the LORD your God and fulfill them; let all the neighboring lands bring gifts to the One to be feared.
Context: This is a call to faithfulness and the honoring of God, also implying the extent of His rule beyond Israel.

Text: He breaks the spirit of princes; He is feared by the kings of the earth.
Context: The verse emphasizes God‘s supremacy over earthly rulers, who, despite their own power, are humbled before Him.
